Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Social Service Organizations and Community Dynamics in Neighborhoods with High Levels of Illegal Activity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research project will investigate the role of social service organizations within the broader dynamics of neighborhoods that have experienced high levels of illegal activity, especially the sale and distribution of illegal drugs. Whereas previous research on illicit activities in urban neighborhoods often have been framed by the larger literature on the global drug trade and the "War on Drugs" approach to policing, this project adopts an approach that strives to understand the full range of individual and organizational interactions and relationships in a community. The theoretical foundations of this project seek to describe and understand the complex social networks of support, reciprocity, power, and violence that include the drug trade and a broad range of related activities. That work has explored how individuals engage in informal economic activities as well as how they function as community members in other ways. The research project supported by this award will focus on the ways in which social service organizations function to offer programming that works to quell the drug economy, often through a range of job readiness programs that explicitly transition people from informal and illicit work to formal employment. Working in a neighborhood in south Philadelphia that has had high drug-related crime levels, the doctoral student will conduct interviews with employees and volunteers associated with these organizations in order to develop a deeper understanding of the external pressures on the illegal economy that are situated immediately in the neighborhood. Interviews will include questions about the programming, mission, goals, and measures of success as well as the experiences of organizations in the community, the ways programs are received by target populations, and perceptions of the drug trade and its role in the community. Information gathered through these interviews will be integrated with information previously gathered through ethnographic research and oral histories in order to develop more comprehensive, multi-dimensional knowledge about the complex interactions of social service organizations and others interacting in the study site and similar communities.

This project will provide a range of new theoretical perspectives. It will contribute to the growing body of scholarship that illustrates the connections linking economy, community, and identity across scales. It will help refine perspectives that consider the decision-making strategies of drug economy participants at the level of household and community relationships by assessing how they make meaningful decisions about themselves, their families, their communities, and their cities. It also will provide new insights regarding how social service programs are interpreted and used by those engaged in illicit activities and those with whom they interact. Project results will assist community organizations in addressing drug-related issues in their neighborhoods, thereby contributing new information and insights that may improve their outreach and educational efforts. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this award also will provide support to enable a promising student to establish a strong independent research career.

Project Summary

This study forms part of a larger dissertation project that studies how African-American, inner-city neighborhoods have, for decades, survived at the margins of the economy. The drug economy is far from ideal practice, especially for those under correctional supervision; yet, it persists as one of the few viable options for many ex-offenders. The central objective of the funded study is to investigate the path to re-entry for people returning to Grays Ferry, Philadelphia after serving prison sentences for drug-related crimes. This project examines the challenges former offenders face as they seek to reestablish themselves in their communities.

 

The study’s methodology combined a twelve-month ethnography with archival work, oral histories of community members and interviews with employees and volunteers at local community organizations and nonprofits aimed at providing services to people who work in informal, and often criminal, economies. The data set collected consists of recorded observations, interview transcripts and secondary sources (mainly newspapers and policy documents).

 

Intellectual Merit

This study contributes to geography and cognate disciplines by integrating the well-developed theoretical and methodological lens of feminist geography and critical race studies with the tradition of developing a place-based understanding of life and crime in US inner-cities. There is little work that explicitly studies community processes in relation to the drug economy, including the experiences of incarceration and reintegration of community members. Through a community study of the processes that create a complex informal economy, in which the drug economy forms an important part, this study offers insights into how people understand the challenges and risks associated with this economy in their everyday lives. Such understanding is essential for improving services designed to diminish criminal activity, incarceration and violence in inner cities.

 

Broader Impacts

The major impacts of this study are two-fold. First, the study findings suggest policies that could both curb the drug economy and reduce recidivism. By examining the economic needs of residents in Grays Ferry, the project develops a deeper understanding of the livelihood decisions driving residents’ participation in the drug economy. Second, the project suggests economic development policies that are practical and appealing for people whose employment needs are not currently being met. It does so by developing an understanding of the skill set and the needs of residents participating in the informal economy.

 

The research findings have the potential to guide policy and programming for local community organizations and nonprofits that offer a variety of economic-based services to neighborhood residents in need. In addition to in-person dissemination, the project findings will be published online in easily accessible formats (i.e. brochures and factsheets) for download by any community organization with Internet access. This project has been presented and published in academic forums as well, contributing to a growing body of public scholarship that attempts to create place-based, community driven economic development models.
